body.p: In revising the definition, the Board adopted the following approach:

li.p: When an entity assesses whether two parties are related, it would treat significant influence as equivalent to the relationship that exists between an entity and a member of its key management personnel. However, those relationships are not as close as a relationship of control or joint control.
If two entities are both subject to control (or joint control) by the same entity or person, the two entities are related to each other.

If one entity (or person) controls (or jointly controls) a second entity and the first entity (or person) has significant influence over a third entity, the second and third entities are related to each other.
Conversely, if two entities are both subject to significant influence by the same entity (or person), the two entities are not related to each other.
If the revised definition treats one party as related to a second party, the definition should also treat the second party as related to the first party, by symmetry.
